discussion and possible action regarding
the proposed order in docket number 2021
a.d mississippi public service commuter
commission's
net metering and interconnection rules
final order amending rules mistakes
thank you mr chairman
um as you know
this docket was originally opened in
january 2021 pursuant to a reopener
directive of the original december 2015
order adopting net metering um in order
to contemplate any necessary revisions
to the rules
after opening the docket multiple
parties filed written comments which
were reviewed by the commission and
incorporated into a draft rule that was
published both in this docket and with
the secretary of state pursuant to the
administrative procedures act in january
of this year
additional written comments were then
solicited by the commission and reviewed
and a public hearing was conducted
immediately following the open meeting
on march 1st
after carefully considering all of the
written comments as well as the
testimony presented at the public
hearing commission staff has prepared a
final order amending the rules in
pertinent part as follows
first the names of the rules and
terminology throughout them were amended
to reference quote net renewable
generation as opposed to the previous
term of net metering
these changes were made to better
reflect the type of
distributed generation program that's
made available under the rules which is
not traditional net metering but rather
a more general compensation program for
behind the meter distributed generation
the order retains the 2.5 cents per
kilowatt hour distributed generation
adder but it grandfathers it in for a
period of 25 years
the low income benefits adder is
likewise grandfathered in for 25 years
eligibility for the low income benefits
adder has been expanded and now includes
customers with annual household incomes
of up to 250 percent of the federal
poverty level
the rule now includes meter aggregation
provisions which will allow customers
with multiple meters to use energy
generated by one dg system to offset
their usage on all eligible meters to be
eligible for meter aggregation all
meters must be located either on the
same premises or within one mile or
excuse me or within the same
eu service terry territory that
encompasses the dg system
dg customers are no longer required to
transfer the renewable energy credits to
their utilities as a condition of
receiving the 2.5 per kilowatt hour
distributed generation benefit adder
however if a customer elects to receive
an upfront rebate which is something
that we'll discuss in a minute
the customer may be required to transfer
their wrecks to the utility as a
condition of receiving that rebate
the definition of net generation has
been revised to note that special
metering requirements will will be
obviated
in circumstances where advanced metering
infrastructure or smart meters are
utilized
the rule now expressly states that
battery storage systems will not affect
the total name nameplate capacity of a
customer's dg system the system capacity
limits under the rule will now be
measured in terms of alternating current
rather than direct current
the previous hard set three percent
participation cap has been modified and
increased
now utilities may seek commission
approval to to refuse additional uh
customers dg customers if and when
participation reaches four percent
of the utilities total system peak
demand
similarly rather than including a
mandatory reopener provision for the
commission
the rule now permits the commission to
exercise its discretion in deciding
whether or not to reopen a rule making
for additional changes at the earliest
of either five years from the date of
this order or at the point at which
total net distributed generation
capacity reaches four percent of the
utility system peak demand
the utilities annual net generation
reports must now also include the total
number of dg customers that receive the
low income benefits adder
and finally the working group provision
of the rules has been retitled and
revised to expand the purpose of the
group beyond consumer protection
now a joint interagency working group
shall meet biannually for the continued
monitoring discussion and consideration
of the efficacy and fairness of the
rules
and shall present any recommended action
items to the commission by january 30 of
each year
in addition to these specific amendments
to the rules themselves the proposed
order sets forth other provisions
instructing the utilities to make
separate filings for the approval of
solar for schools programs and upfront
rebates for distributed generation
systems mr hammonds is prepared to
describe these provisions in more detail
okay
thank you commissioners uh as you all
are aware the commission's january 18
2022 order found that
two provisions both the rebates and a
solar for schools program

itself there was a directive for the
utilities to make those filings

kind of highlighting those
